'Yaa' is a letter of calling or addressing, e.g. you say 'Oh' so and so.%0D%0ASo, if 'Yaa' comes before a name or person, it will mean calling or%0D%0Aaddressing him, e.g. al-Rajul means the man and 'Yaa Rajul' means 'O man'.%0D%0AMessengers and prophets (Alayhis salaam) are chosen people by Allah Ta'ala%0D%0Aand are sinless servants of Allah. A nabi (Alayhis salaam) is he who follows%0D%0Athe messengers before him and a Rasul is sent with his own book and new%0D%0Alaws, e.g. Tawraat, Injeel, etc.%0D%0AIn the English terminology, as commonly used nowadays, both messengers and%0D%0Aprophets are synonymous to each other. However, in the strict Arabic%0D%0Aterminology, there is a difference between Rasool and Nabi as explained%0D%0Aabove.
